Description: Cardinal Health agreed to pay $34 million in civil penalties to resolve allegations that the distributor failed to report to the Drug Enforcement Administration suspicious orders of Class II controlled substances by pharmacies located in central Florida and Maryland.  The settlement also resolved a civil investigation in the Western District of Washington into Cardinal Health's failure to maintain adequate records concerning Class II controlled substances in that district.

Costco Wholesale agreed to pay $11.75 million to settle allegations that its pharmacies violated the Controlled Substances Act when they filled prescriptions for controlled substances that were incomplete, lacked valid Drug Enforcement Administration (DEA) numbers or were for substances beyond various doctors' scope of practice.

CVS Pharmacy, Inc. admitted that it unlawfully sold pseudoephedrine to criminals who made methamphetamine. As part of the agreement with federal prosecutors, CVS agreed to pay $75 million in civil penalties and to forfeit the $2.6 million in profits the company earned as a result of the illegal conduct.
Info Source: CVS to Pay Largest Ever Civil Penalty Under Controlled Substances Act, Targeted News Service, October 14, 2010 (via Nexis).

Description: CVS Pharmacy Inc. and Oklahoma CVS Pharmacy L.L.C. agreed to pay $11,000,000 to the United States to settle civil penalty claims for record-keeping violations under the Controlled Substances Act and related regulations.

Express Scripts, Inc. and Express Scripts Pharmacy Services, Inc. agreed to pay $ 2.75 million to settle the case against the companies. DEA Philadelphia Diversion Group 1 inspected company locations in Pennsylvania and discovered numerous instances of drug diversion and regulatory violations.
Info Source: DEA Investigation of Express Scripts Drug Diversion, Regulatory Violations Leads to $2.75 Million Settlement, Targeted News Service, May 17, 2012 (via Nexis).

Description: Kaiser Foundation Health System Inc. paid $850,000 to settle allegations that a Kaiser Permanente pharmacy in Modesto violated the Controlled Substances Act by improperly filling defective prescriptions and by failing to maintain accurate records.

Mallinckrodt LLC, a pharmaceutical manufacturer and one of the largest manufacturers of generic oxycodone, agreed to pay $35 million to settle allegations that it violated certain provisions of the Controlled Substances Act that are subject to civil penalties.

Masters Pharmaceutical, Inc. agreed to pay $500,000 to settle claims that it provided controlled substances to illegally operating Internet pharmacies and failed to report these suspicious sales to the Drug Enforcement Administration.
Info Source: Ohio Pharmaceutical Wholesaler Agrees to Pay $500,000 in Civil Settlement for Supplying Internet Pharmacies, States News Service, May 4, 2009 (via Nexis).

Description: McKesson Corporation, a large distributor of pharmaceutical drugs, agreed to pay a $150 million civil penalty for alleged violations of the Controlled Substances Act relating to the failure to report suspicious orders of products such as oxycodone and hydrocodone.

Omnicare, Inc. agreed to pay a $50 million civil penalty to resolve claims its various pharmacy facilities improperly dispensed controlled substances to patients at long-term care facilities across the country.
Info Source: Omnicare in $50 Million Settlement-Largest Controlled Substance Settlement in History, Targeted News Service, May 11, 2012 (via Nexis).
DEA Diversion Investigation Leads to $500,000 Settlement in Internet Pharmacy Case, Targeted News Service, April 30, 2012 (via Nexis).

Description: Rite Aid Corporation paid $834,200 in civil penalties to the United States to settle claims stemming from alleged violations of the Controlled Substances Act.? The settlement was part of an agreement to resolve allegations that certain Rite Aid pharmacies in Los Angeles dispensed and/or recorded controlled substances using a medical practitioner's incorrect or invalid DEA registration number.
Rite Aid Corporation and nine of its subsidiaries in eight states agreed to pay $5 million in civil penalties to settle allegations of violations of the Controlled Substances Act.
Info Source: Rite Aid Corporation and Subsidiaries Agree to Pay $5 Million in Civil Penalties to Resolve Violations in Eight States of Controlled Substances Act, States News Service, January 12, 2009 (via Nexis).

Recap of Ownership Changes: Safeway was acquired in 2015 by Albertsons, a majority of which was held by Cerberus Capital Management until 2021.
Description: The Department of Justice and Safeway (a division of Albertsons Companies, Inc.) reached a civil settlement of allegations the company failed to timely report controlled substances that were missing from pharmacies. Safeway agreed to pay the United States $3 million and implement a compliance agreement reached with the Drug Enforcement Administration to ensure such notification lapses do not happen again.

St.Vincent Hospital of Indianapolis agreed to pay the United States $2 million to settle alleged record keeping deficiencies regarding its receipt and storage of controlled substances at its clinic pharmacy.
Info Source: Hospital's Failure to Keep Proper Records Results in $2 Million Civil Fine, US Fed News, July 26, 2007 (via Nexis).

Description: Walgreens agreed to pay $80 million to resolve what the DEA called an unprecedented number of record-keeping and dispensing violations under the Controlled Substances Act.
CVS Pharmacy, Inc. agreed to pay $535,000 to resolve allegations that several of its Rhode Island stores violated the federal Controlled Substances Act by filling invalid prescriptions.

Omnicare Inc., a subsidiary of CVS Health and a leading provider of pharmacy services to long-term care facilities, agreed to pay the United States a $15.3 million civil penalty to resolve allegations that it violated federal law by allowing opioids and other controlled substances to be dispensed without a valid prescription.
The hospital was alleged to have employed a physician who wrote prescriptions for controlled substances without legitimate medical purposes and outside the usual course of professional practice.

Company: University of Texas Southwestern Medical Center
Description: The University of Texas Southwestern Medical Center agreed to pay $4.5 million to resolve allegations that its violations of the Controlled Substances Act allowed hospital staff to divert fentanyl and other dangerous drugs from the hospital.

Olive Street Pharmacy, LLC and a pharmacy technician agreed to pay $1,507,808.50 to resolve a civil complaint bringing claims under the False Claims Act and Controlled Substances Act related to the unlawful dispensing of controlled substances, including some that were submitted to Medicaid or Medicare for reimbursement.
